review.title: Are there intelligent Turing machines?
review.abstract: This paper introduces a new computing model based on the cooperation among Turing machines called orchestrated machines. Like universal Turing machines, orchestrated machines are also designed to simulate Turing machines but they can also modify the original operation of the included Turing machines to create a new layer of some kind of collective behavior. Using this new model we can define some interested notions related to cooperation ability of Turing machines such as the intelligence quotient or the emotional intelligence quotient for Turing machines.

metadata.title: Are there intelligent Turing machines?

sections.text: Keywords: calculation methods, machine intelligence, Turing machines.

sections.heading: 1.1 Notations and background
sections.text: According to the notation used in this work, the quadruple G = (QG, 0, {0, 1}, fG) shall be a Turing machine (TM) with the partial transition function fG: QG × {0, 1} → QG × {←, ↑, →, 0 х QG, N.In the course of this work, M shall designate the set of Turing machines with specified n or less states and F → T-fG shall designate a transitional rule of the machine G-M, in the F-QG × {0, 1} and T-QG × {0, 1} × {←, ↑, →. Special machines shall also be specified in the form of control index notations shown in [2]. For example, the famous 5-state champion Turing machine of Marxen and Buntrock may be (9, 0, 11, 1, 15, 15, 15, 17, 24, 24, 17, 24, 24, 24, 24, 24, etc.).

sections.heading: 2 Orchestrated cooperation among Turing ma-
sections.text: China In an intuitive sense, we call Turing machines that are able to cooperate with each other using some kind of algorithm such as Alg. 1, Alg. 4 or Alg. 5 orchestrated machines (OMs) The idea behind these algorithms is to modify the original operation of Turing machines to develop collective behavior. The name Orchestrated machines is partly inspired by the Penrose - Hameroff Orchestrated Objective Reduction (OrchOR) model of quantum consciousness [5].The taste of our algorithms in question is reminiscent of the dynamics of Neumann's U and R processes [15] and the dynamics of the intuitive Cell Automation Example [5] in the sense that a transition rule is selected non-deterministically from applicable rules (R), then this selected rule is executed in all Turing machines (U), and so on.

sections.heading: 2.1 Orchestrated machines
sections.text: The complete pseudo-code for orchestrated machines is in Alg. 1. As input, the algorithm receives a series of Turing machines. The initial state of the orchestrated machine is that the heads of the Turing machines contained read zero and the machines are in their initial state, which can be applicable to the actual value of the machines. If a machine G does not have such a rule, then it pauses and is removed from the orchestrated machine in line 10. The main loop gathers the right side of the applicable rules of the machines G → T-fG in line 8 (the implementation uses a list).

sections.heading: 2.1.1 Orchestrated machines with input
sections.text: To simplify the construction of concrete Turing machines, the {0, 1,} -band alphabet is used in Alg. 4, but the input alphabet remains binary. The change of Alg. 1 is represented in the pseudo-code of Alg. 4, where modified lines are included. (1) Algorithm 4, ordered machines (with the same input) are the first letter of the input word. (1) The change of Alg. 1 is the input word. (1): Procedure OrchMach2 (M0, w). 3: F = (0, a). a) The input words are the first letter of the input word. 24: end ExdureIn the following, we allow it. (0, 1) a given type word. The OrchMach1 (H) algorithm is a special case of OrchMach2 (H, w), where the input word is empty.

sections.heading: 2.2 Universal orchestrated machines
sections.text: Alg. 5 yields the pseudo-code for universally orchestrated machines. It allows a higher autonomy for individual Turing machines in their operation. If we compare this orchestrated algorithm with the algorithms given in earlier sections, we will easily recognize the difference, the variable F, which represents the actual state, and the symbol read is a local variable in the sense that each machine of a breed has its own variable F. In this essay we do not examine the properties of OrchMach3, but only the algorithm represented in Alg. 5, but it is clear that theorem 1 does not apply to universally orchestrated machines. Algorithm 5 Orchestrated machines (with different inputs) Input: M0 M, wi M, i = 1,.., Map (M0). wi is the input word of the machine Ri M0 n N, N M2, Mn Mn M, Gn.

sections.heading: 3 Conclusion and future directions
sections.text: We have introduced a new special type of universal Turing machine called orchestrated machine, which makes it possible to examine the a'priori ability of certain Turing machines to work with each other. Among purebred machine types, we have defined two unpredictable overall functions EQ and IQ to catalyze the search for more interesting types of machinery.In this paper, the time complexity of orchestrated machines has not been investigated, but it is clear that the NP OM1P, where OM1P denotes the class of decision problems that can be solved by an orchestrated machine (with OrchMach1 algorithm) in polynomial time.This inclusion follows from theorem 3. We have many other exciting and unanswered questions for future research. In this paper, for example, the orchestrated machines were built from turing machines. Is it possible that an orchestrated machine can be constructed from orchestrated machines (if we believe that machine cyclopediments are good for each other).

sections.heading: Acknowledgment
sections.text: Some of the calculations presented in this paper were performed on the NIIF High Performance Computing Supercomputer at the University of Debrecen.

Using this new model we can define some interested notions related to cooperation ability of Turing machines such as the intelligence quotient or the emotional intelligence quotient for Turing machines.
